issues.title: `abi.encodePacked()` Hash Collision
issues.description: abi.encodePacked() should not be used with dynamic types when passing the result to a hash function such as `keccak256()`. Use `abi.encode()` instead which will pad items to 32 bytes, preventing hash collisions: https://docs.soliditylang.org/en/v0.8.13/abi-spec.html#non-standard-packed-mode. (e.g. `abi.encodePacked(0x123,0x456)` => `0x123456` => `abi.encodePacked(0x1,0x23456)`, but `abi.encode(0x123,0x456)` => `0x0...1230...456`). Unless there is a compelling reason, `abi.encode` should be preferred. If there is only one argument to `abi.encodePacked()` it can often be cast to `bytes()` or `bytes32()` instead: https://ethereum.stackexchange.com/questions/30912/how-to-compare-strings-in-solidity#answer-82739. If all arguments are strings and or bytes, `bytes.concat()` should be used instead.

issues.title: Arbitrary `from` Passed to `transferFrom`
issues.description: Passing an arbitrary `from` address to `transferFrom` (or `safeTransferFrom`) can lead to loss of funds, because anyone can transfer tokens from the `from` address if an approval is made.

issues.title: Unprotected initializer
issues.description: Consider protecting the initializer functions with modifiers.

issues.title: Unsafe Casting of integers
issues.description: Downcasting int/uints in Solidity can be unsafe due to the potential for data loss and unintended behavior.When downcasting a larger integer type to a smaller one (e.g., uint256 to uint128), the value may exceed the range of the target type,leading to truncation and loss of significant digits. Use OpenZeppelin's SafeCast library to safely downcast integers.

issues.title: EnumerableSet.remove Corrupts Order
issues.description:
If the order of an EnumerableSet is required, removing items in a loop using `at` and `remove` corrupts this order.
Consider using a different data structure or removing items by collecting them during the loop, then removing after the loop.

issues.title: Experimental ABI Encoder
issues.description: Experimental encoders should not be used in production. There are multiple known compiler bugs that are caused by the experimental encoder. Upgrade your solidity version to remove the need for experimental features.

issues.title: Incorrect Assembly Shift Parameter Order
issues.description: Example: `shl(shifted, 4)` will shift the right constant `4` by `a` bits. The correct order is `shl(4, shifted)`.

issues.title: Storage Array Edited with Memory
issues.description: Storage reference is passed to a function with a memory parameter. This will not update the storage variable as expected. Consider using storage parameters instead.

issues.title: Contract Has Multiple Constructors
issues.description: In some versions of Solidity, contracts compile with multiple constructors. The first constructor takes precedence. This can lead to unexpected behavior.

issues.title: Contract Name Reused in Different Files
issues.description: When compiling contracts with certain development frameworks (for example: Truffle), having contracts with the same name across different files can lead to one being overwritten.

issues.title: Nested Structs in Mappings pre-0.5.0
issues.description: Prior to updates in Solidity 0.5.0, public mappings with nested structs compiled, but produced incorrect values. Refrain from using these, or update to a more recent version of Solidity.

issues.title: `selfdestruct` is Deprecated
issues.description: Remove the `selfdestruct` instruction from the code.

issues.title: Direct assignment of array length
issues.description: If the length of a dynamic array (storage variable) is directly assigned to, it may allow access to other storage slots by tweaking it's value. This practice has been deprecated in newer Solidity versions

issues.title: Incorrect use of caret operator
issues.description: The caret operator is usually mistakenly thought of as an exponentiation operator but actually, it's a bitwise xor operator.

issues.title: Yul block contains `return`
issues.description: This causes the transaction execution to halt, and nothing after that call will execute including code following the assembly block.

issues.title: Shadowed State Variable
issues.description: This vulnerability arises when a derived contract unintentionally shadows a state variable from a parent contract by declaring a variable with the same name. This can be misleading. To prevent this, ensure variable names are unique across the inheritance hierarchy or use proper visibility and scope controls.

issues.title: Unchecked `bool success` value for ETH send
issues.description: The call `address(payable?).send(address)` may fail because of reasons like out-of-gas, invalid recipient address or revert from the recipient, but not revert the transaction. Therefore, the boolean returned by this function call must be checked to be `true` in order to verify that the transaction was successful.

issues.title: Misused boolean with logical operators
issues.description: The patterns `if (â€¦ || true)` and `if (.. && false)` will always evaluate to true and false respectively.

issues.title: ETH transferred without address checks
issues.description: Consider introducing checks for `msg.sender` to ensure the recipient of the money is as intended.

issues.title: `delegatecall` to an Arbitrary Address
issues.description: Making a `delegatecall` to an arbitrary address without any checks is dangerous. Consider adding requirements on the target address.

issues.title: Tautological comparison
issues.description: The left hand side and the right hand side of the binary operation has the same value. This makes the condition always true or always false.

issues.title: RTLO character detected in file: \u{202e}
issues.description: The right to left override character may be misleading and cause potential attacks by visually misordering method arguments.

issues.title: Dangerous unary operator
issues.description: Potentially mistaken `=+` for `+=` or `=-` for `-=`. This acts as an assignment instead of an increment or decrement.Use the correct operator to increment or decrement a variable.

issues.title: Tautology or Contradiction in comparison
issues.description: The condition has been determined to be either always true or always false due to the integer range in which we're operating.

issues.title: Dangerous strict equality checks on contract balances
issues.description: A contract's balance can be forcibly manipulated by another selfdestructing contract. Therefore, it's recommended to use >, <, >= or <= instead of strict equality.

issues.title: Signed integer array in storage (solc `<0.5.10`)
issues.description: solc versions 0.4.7-0.5.9 contain a compiler bug leading to incorrect values in signed integer arrays.Use solidity version 0.5.10 or above.

issues.title: Weak Randomness
issues.description: The use of keccak256 hash functions on predictable values like block.timestamp, block.number, or similar data, including modulo operations on these values, should be avoided for generating randomness, as they are easily predictable and manipulable. The `PREVRANDAO` opcode also should not be used as a source of randomness. Instead, utilize Chainlink VRF for cryptographically secure and provably random values to ensure protocol integrity.

issues.title: Usage of variable before declaration
issues.description: Declare the variable before using it to avoid unintended consequences.

issues.title: Deletion from a nested mapping
issues.description: A deletion in a structure containing a mapping will not delete the mapping. The remaining data may be used to compromise the contract.

issues.title: Use of `tx.origin` for authentication
issues.description: Using `tx.origin` may lead to problems when users are interacting via smart contract with your protocol. It is recommended to use `msg.sender` for authentication.

issues.title: Loop contains `msg.value`
issues.description: Provide an explicit array of amounts alongside the receivers array, and check that the sum of all amounts matches `msg.value`.

issues.title: Contract locks Ether without a withdraw function
issues.description: It appears that the contract includes a payable function to accept Ether but lacks a corresponding function to withdraw it, which leads to the Ether being locked in the contract. To resolve this issue, please implement a public or external function that allows for the withdrawal of Ether from the contract.

issues.title: Incorrect ERC721 interface
issues.description: Incorrect return values for ERC721 functions. A contract compiled with Solidity > 0.4.22 interacting with these functions will fail to execute them, as the return value is missing. Set the appropriate return values and types for the defined ERC721 functions.

issues.title: Incorrect ERC20 interface
issues.description: Incorrect return values for ERC20 functions. A contract compiled with Solidity > 0.4.22 interacting with these functions will fail to execute them, as the return value is missing. Set the appropriate return values and types for the defined ERC20 functions.

issues.title: Out of Order Retryable Transaction
issues.description:
Do not rely on the order or successful execution of retryable tickets. Functions like createRetryableTicket, outboundTransferCustomRefund, unsafeCreateRetryableTicket are free to be re-tried in any
            order if they fail in the first go. Since this operation happens off chain, the sequencer is in control of the
            order of these transactions. Therefore, restrict the use to at most 1 ticket call per function.

issues.title: Constant functions changes state
issues.description: Function is declared constant/view but it changes state. Ensure that the attributes of contract compiled prior to 0.5 are correct.

issues.title: Function Selector Collision
issues.description: Function selector collides with other functions. This may cause the solidity function dispatcher to invoke the wrong function if the functions happen to be included in the same contract through an inheritance hierarchy later down the line. It is recommended to rename this function or change its parameters.

instances.hint: collides with the following function name(s) in scope: OwnerTransferV7b711143
collides with the following function name(s) in scope: withdraw

issues.title: Unchecked Low level calls
issues.description: The return value of the low-level call is not checked, so if the call fails, the Ether will be locked in the contract. If the low level is used to prevent blocking operations, consider logging failed calls. Ensure that the return value of a low-level call is checked or logged.

issues.title: Reentrancy: State change after external call
issues.description: Changing state after an external call can lead to re-entrancy attacks.Use the checks-effects-interactions pattern to avoid this issue.

instances.hint: State is changed at: `swapEnabled = true`, `tradingOpen = true`, `firstBlock = block.number`
State is changed at: `swapEnabled = true`, `tradingOpen = true`, `firstBlock = block.number`
State is changed at: `swapEnabled = true`, `tradingOpen = true`, `firstBlock = block.number`

issues.title: `delegatecall` in loop
issues.description: Using `delegatecall` in loop may consume excessive gas, or worse, lead to more severe issues.

issues.title: Centralization Risk
issues.description: Contracts have owners with privileged rights to perform admin tasks and need to be trusted to not perform malicious updates or drain funds.

issues.title: Solmate's SafeTransferLib
issues.description:
There is a subtle difference between the implementation of solmate's SafeTransferLib and OZ's SafeERC20: OZ's SafeERC20 checks if the token is a contract or not, solmate's SafeTransferLib does not.
https://github.com/transmissions11/solmate/blob/main/src/utils/SafeTransferLib.sol#L9 
`@dev Note that none of the functions in this library check that a token has code at all! That responsibility is delegated to the caller`

issues.title: `ecrecover` Signature Malleability
issues.description: The `ecrecover` function is susceptible to signature malleability. This means that the same message can be signed in multiple ways, allowing an attacker to change the message signature without invalidating it. This can lead to unexpected behavior in smart contracts, such as the loss of funds or the ability to bypass access control. Consider using OpenZeppelin's ECDSA library instead of the built-in function.

issues.title: Deprecated OpenZeppelin Function
issues.description: Openzeppelin has deprecated several functions and replaced with newer versions. Please consult https://docs.openzeppelin.com/

issues.title: Unsafe ERC20 Operation
issues.description: ERC20 functions may not behave as expected. For example: return values are not always meaningful. It is recommended to use OpenZeppelin's SafeERC20 library.

issues.title: Unspecific Solidity Pragma
issues.description: Consider using a specific version of Solidity in your contracts instead of a wide version. For example, instead of `pragma solidity ^0.8.0;`, use `pragma solidity 0.8.0;`

issues.title: Address State Variable Set Without Checks
issues.description: Check for `address(0)` when assigning values to address state variables.

issues.title: Public Function Not Used Internally
issues.description: If a function is marked public but is not used internally, consider marking it as `external`.

issues.title: Literal Instead of Constant
issues.description: Define and use `constant` variables instead of using literals. If the same constant literal value is used multiple times, create a constant state variable and reference it throughout the contract.

issues.title: Empty `require()` / `revert()` Statement
issues.description: Use descriptive reason strings or custom errors for revert paths.

issues.title: `nonReentrant` is Not the First Modifier
issues.description: To protect against reentrancy in other modifiers, the `nonReentrant` modifier should be the first modifier in the list of modifiers.

issues.title: Using `block.timestamp` for swap deadline offers no protection
issues.description: In the PoS model, proposers know well in advance if they will propose one or consecutive blocks ahead of time. In such a scenario, a malicious validator can hold back the transaction and execute it at a more favourable block number.Consider allowing function caller to specify swap deadline input parameter.

issues.title: Unsafe `ERC721::_mint()`
issues.description: Using `ERC721::_mint()` can mint ERC721 tokens to addresses which don't support ERC721 tokens. Use `_safeMint()` instead of `_mint()` for ERC721 tokens.

issues.title: PUSH0 Opcode
issues.description: Solc compiler version 0.8.20 switches the default target EVM version to Shanghai, which means that the generated bytecode will include PUSH0 opcodes. Be sure to select the appropriate EVM version in case you intend to deploy on a chain other than mainnet like L2 chains that may not support PUSH0, otherwise deployment of your contracts will fail.

issues.title: Modifier Invoked Only Once
issues.description: Consider removing the modifier or inlining the logic into the calling function.

issues.title: Empty Block
issues.description: Consider removing empty blocks.

issues.title: Large Numeric Literal
issues.description: Large literal values multiples of 10000 can be replaced with scientific notation.Use `e` notation, for example: `1e18`, instead of its full numeric value.

issues.title: Internal Function Used Only Once
issues.description: Instead of separating the logic into a separate function, consider inlining the logic into the calling function. This can reduce the number of function calls and improve readability.

issues.title: Contract has TODO Comments
issues.description: Contract contains comments with TODOS. Consider implementing or removing them.

issues.title: Inconsistent uint256/uint (or) int256/int types
issues.description: Inconsistency in declaring uint256/uint (or) int256/int variables within a contract. Use explicit size declarations (uint256 or int256). Consider keeping the naming convention consistent in a given contract. Explicit size declarations are preferred (uint256, int256) over implicit ones (uint, int) to avoid confusion.

issues.title: Unused Error
issues.description: Consider using or removing the unused error.

issues.title: Loop Contains `require`/`revert`
issues.description: Avoid `require` / `revert` statements in a loop because a single bad item can cause the whole transaction to fail. It's better to forgive on fail and return failed elements post processing of the loop

issues.title: Incorrect Order of Division and Multiplication
issues.description:
Division operations followed directly by multiplication operations can lead to precision loss due to the way integer arithmetic is handled in Solidity./
        Consider Multiplication before Division.

issues.title: Redundant Statement
issues.description: Remove the redundant statement.

issues.title: State Variable is Read as External
issues.description: The contract reads it's own state variable using `this` which adds an unnecessary STATICCALL. Consider removing `this` to access the variable from storage.

issues.title: Unused State Variable
issues.description: State variable appears to be unused. No analysis has been performed to see if any inline assembly references it. Consider removing this unused variable.

issues.title: Constant Function Contains Assembly
issues.description: constant/pure/view was not enforced prior to Solidity 0.5. Starting from Solidity 0.5, a call to a constant/pure/view function uses the STATICCALL opcode, which reverts in case of state modification. As a result, a call to an incorrectly labeled function may trap a contract compiled with Solidity 0.5. https://docs.soliditylang.org/en/develop/050-breaking-changes.html#interoperability-with-older-contracts

issues.title: Boolean equality is not required
issues.description: If `x` is a boolean, use `if(x)` and `if(!x)` instead of `if(x == true)` or `if(x == false)`.

issues.title: Local Variable Shadows State Variable
issues.description: Rename the local variable that shadows another state variable.

issues.title: Uninitialized Local Variable
issues.description: Initialize all the variables. If a variable is meant to be initialized to zero, explicitly set it to zero to improve code readability.

issues.title: Return Bomb
issues.description: A low level callee may consume all callers gas unexpectedly. Avoid unlimited implicit decoding of returndata on calls to unchecked addresses. You can limit the gas by passing a gas limit as an option to the call. For example, `unknownAddress.call{gas: gasLimitHere}("calldata")` That would act as a safety net from OOG errors.

issues.title: Function Used to Initialize State Variable
issues.description: Instead of using a function to initialize a state variable in its declaration; declare the state variable and initialize it in the constructor.

issues.title: Dead Code
issues.description: Functions that are not used. Consider removing them.

issues.title: Storage Array Length not Cached
issues.description: Calling `.length` on a storage array in a loop condition is expensive. Consider caching the length in a local variable in memory before the loop and reusing it.

issues.title: State change in `assert()` statement
issues.description: An argument to `assert()` modifies the state. Use `require` for invariants modifying state.

issues.title: Costly operations inside loop
issues.description: Invoking `SSTORE` operations in loops may waste gas. Use a local variable to hold the loop computation result.

issues.title: Builtin Symbol Shadowing
issues.description: Name clashes with a built-in-symbol. Consider renaming it.

issues.title: Void constructor
issues.description: Call to a constructor that is not implemented.

issues.title: Missing Inheritance
issues.description: There is an interface / abstract contract that is potentially missing (not included in) the inheritance of this contract.

instances.hint: Is this contract supposed to implement an interface? Consider extending one of the following: IMissingInheritanceCounter
Is this contract supposed to implement an interface? Consider extending one of the following: IMissingChild, IMissingParent
Is this contract supposed to implement an interface? Consider extending one of the following: IERC20

issues.title: Unused Import
issues.description: Redundant import statement. Consider removing it.

issues.title: Function Pointer in Constructor
issues.description: solc versions below 0.5.9 contain a compiler bug leading to unexpected behavior when calling uninitialized function pointers in constructors. It is recommended to not use function pointers in constructors.

issues.title: State Variable Could Be Constant
issues.description: State variables that are not updated following deployment should be declared constant to save gas. Add the `constant` attribute to state variables that never change.

issues.title: State Change Without Event
issues.description: There are state variable changes in this function but no event is emitted. Consider emitting an event to enable offchain indexers to track the changes.

issues.title: State Variable Could Be Immutable
issues.description: State variables that are only changed in the constructor should be declared immutable to save gas. Add the `immutable` attribute to state variables that are only changed in the constructor

issues.title: Multiple Placeholders in Modifier
issues.description: Design the modifier to only contain 1 placeholder statement. If that is not possible, split the logic into multiple modifiers.

issues.title: Incorrect Use Of Modifier
issues.description: If a modifier does not execute `_` or revert, the execution of the function will return the default value, which can be misleading for the caller. It is recommended that all the paths in a modifier must execute _ or revert.

issues.title: Unchecked Return
issues.description: Function returns a value but it is ignored. Consider checking the return value.
